content.description: "Climb the large tooth-like boulder. Dirty. This one got its name inspiration from the similarly-shaped stone found on Happy's of Bishop." -Mike Snyder, Cody Bouldering Guide.
content.protection: Would recommend 2+ crash pads. Janky fall zone that's also pretty rocky.
content.location: Walk past the Cheese Boulder and around the Ripper boulder, and there it is. Not hard to spot.

content.description: Start on the obvious northeast-facing slab to the right of the crack. Work your way up on small and kind of weird features. Top out. A nice break from the power-heavy routes of Mid Mountain.
content.protection: Multiple pads and a spotter. Relatively good fallzone though.
content.location: Walk to the right of the cheese Boulder and towards Ripper. The route is to the right of the dihedral.

content.description: Work good crimps along the lip until they end.  Make a big throw or tic tac edges and the arete to get the slopey crimp.  Straight up to the jug and top out.  An old school V5, now widely thought to be stiff at V6 and unfortunately the yardstick for many other V5's on the mountain.
content.protection: Flat dirt landing, easy to pad.
content.location: Climbs the obvious arete at the left adge of the steep wall on the back of the Ripper Boulder.

climbs.name: Ripper Extension
climbs.fa: anyone chime in if you remember

content.description: Start same as Ripper Point but continue right on the steep face instead of going onto the slab. Avoiding the dab on the boulder at your back detracts from the experience, but its still a good line.
content.protection: couple of pads and spotter for the dab boulder
content.location: North face of the Ripper Boulder

content.description: Climb the left trending finger crack to the top and walk off left. The climb is significantly harder from the sitting position, which gives it the V2 rating, otherwise considered V0.
content.protection: Just a crash pad if you feel like it.
content.location: Locate the cheese traverse boulder; it's the boulder behind it, walking around right.

content.description: Short but... Midly sweet. Start with your left on the arete and your right on a Gaston. Move your way up using crimps on the face.
content.location: When you enter Mid mountain, this is the first boulder in your right.

content.description: Start at the large crack on the right side of the boulder move up to a flat sloper and then up the crimps on the left side of the round arete.
A strange, and strangely difficult route. That's about it.
content.location: Located on Bear Hug, the first boulder on the right when you enter Mid Mountain area.

content.description: Start at the horizontal crack in a sit down start. Work straight up. Big moves, but good holds.
content.location: On the left-most side of the Cheese Boulder.

content.description: A very clean and popular boulder. Start at the wide crack on the right side and traverse left. When you reach the really good jug, go for the top-out.
content.protection: Even a crash pad might be unnecessary on this boulder. The ground around the area is very level and with plenty of space to put your stuff.
content.location: The most obvious boulder in the Mid Mountain area.

content.description: The name says it all. Squeeze both aretes all the way up.
content.location: This route is on the the first boulder to your right when you enter Mid mountain area.
